results.title: Entities
results.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.creator_credit_for_label: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.description:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.
description_for_label:

Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

results.title: Videogames supercut
results.brief_description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups.

constellations_primary.name: Action, emotion and videogames
constellations_primary.description: More and more, videogames are beginning to favour emotion as much as action, just like their film and TV cousins.

results.description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.
description_for_label: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.

results.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
results.material_description: Video loop, artist and Michael Bonner (performer)
results.brief_description: Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

constellations_primary.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_primary.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.title_for_label: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
results.description:
Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

“This is a violent black tragedy, a cathartic melodrama. Dressed in a tall ship hat pretending to be a colonialist, the Mirning artist writes with her feather quill back to the colonial-mother-monarch of her times ‘down among the wild men’. From the shade of the gum tree. At the same time as her chronicling, she is attacked by a wild man, (fellow sovereign Yanyuwa artist), who with a super large fork pretend stabs her in the back and the pretend explorer/tall ship coloniser collapses. Even the trees are scared of us blackfellas the hand holding the tree is shaking in fear. The background soundtrack that the viewer cannot hear is us all laughing maniacally at the re-enactment of the anthropological and colonial gaze.” - Ali Gumillya Baker
description_for_label:
Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

“This is a violent black tragedy, a cathartic melodrama. Dressed in a tall ship hat pretending to be a colonialist, the Mirning artist writes with her feather quill back to the colonial-mother-monarch of her times ‘down among the wild men’. From the shade of the gum tree. At the same time as her chronicling, she is attacked by a wild man, (fellow sovereign Yanyuwa artist), who with a super large fork pretend stabs her in the back and the pretend explorer/tall ship coloniser collapses. Even the trees are scared of us blackfellas the hand holding the tree is shaking in fear. The background soundtrack that the viewer cannot hear is us all laughing maniacally at the re-enactment of the anthropological and colonial gaze.” - Ali Gumillya Baker

results.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.brief_description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague.

constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title_for_label: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.description:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague
description_for_label:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague

results.title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
results.credit_line:
Cinematography by Brad Gibb 
Edited by Ben Lane  
Special thanks to Wayne Miller
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 4:12 min
results.brief_description: Shelley Ware’s film Where the Desert Meets the Sea (2020) tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.
results.description:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Currently, Ware hosts the AFL.com web show ‘Colour of Your Jumper’. Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware
description_for_label:

Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Single-channel video, 7:39 mins.
Filmed and edited by Romaine Moreton
Co-directed by Romaine Moreton and Lou Bennett AM
ACMI Collection

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet
Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM
Arranged by Iain Grandage
Produced by Stephen Snelleman
results.brief_description:
2021, Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Filmed & Edited by Romaine Moreton, Co-Directed by Romaine Moreton & Lou Bennett AM
H264 projection,16:9, colour, 7:39 mins
Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet, Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM, Arranged by Iain Grandage, Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Dr Lou Bennett is a Performer, Songwriter, Musical and Artistic Director, Composer, Actor, Soundscape Designer and Academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the Arts to enhance community health and wellbeing. Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of story-telling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.

The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within country, and from this place of rooted calmness, country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.

results.title: Yanmeeyarr
results.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
results.material_description:
Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
results.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Light and shadow have been a powerful storytelling tool long before they were the basis for the moving image. For thousands of generations in Australia, First Peoples storytelling has harnessed the movement of the world and play of light: the special glow of sunset to catch the movement of dancing feet, the flickering campfire as tales are told in the night, the story of stars and constellations told in the Dreaming.

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

“Where does moving image originate? Shadow and light, elemental movement and action; see figures in formation, ceremony in the circle, moving, in rhythm, in rhyme with the heartbeat, sunlight, moon shadow, Yanmeeyarr… flickering in firelight. Dancers painted and adorned, in corroboree, in ceremony, telling story through the dance. The viewer in movement and reflection becomes part of the dance, as the figures become animated. Yanmeeyarr, flickering in the firelight, is reflected in the present; the viewer and the new technologies of today, become part of the work and the ongoing past-present-future of our storytelling continuum.” – Vicki Couzens

Yanmeeyarr is generously supported by the Sidney Myer Fund

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.
